entries.text:
We're a growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications.
We're looking for talented, motivated professionals committed to flawless work and customer service.
Email resume: 106686-CS-6734@grantstreet.hrmdirect.com
entries.title: We're Hiring Telecommuters - Grant Street Group

entries.text: After a year of development a new version of Bugzilla has been released.
entries.title: Release of Bugzilla 4.4 and 4.2.6

entries.text: This is the unofficial launch of the Perl Maven Pro service. If you'd like to get more Perl articles and if you are willing to pay for the privilege, this is for you. (Officially it will only launch on 1 June, but 5 minutes after publishing the page I already saw the first subscriber. I'll find something extra to give the early birds who register before the official launch date.
entries.title: Perl Maven Pro

entries.text: As with every upgrade we can expect that upgrading to perl 5.18 will break some code. Luckily the CPAN Testers provide a very good overview of which modules work and which stopped working due to changes in perl. David Oswald calls on all CPAN authors to make sure their module works on perl 5.18 as well. If you work in a corporate environment, it might be a good idea to check if all your dependencies and also your code works on 5.18. (See the other entry in Which David Golden explains how to set up multiple versions of perl on the same machine.)
entries.title: A call to action for CPAN authors

entries.author: tokuhiro_matsuno
entries.text: Perl::MinimumVersion::Fast created by Tokuhiro Matsuno is 'just' 33 times faster than Perl::MinimumVersion. Oh. Oh!
entries.title: Compiler::Lexer is awesome / Shipped Perl::MinimumVersion::Fast

entries.text: I posted this article on blogs.perl.org trying to explain why translating the Perl Tutorial is important and trying to get more people to help with the translations and the promotion of the translations.
entries.title: Making Perl more accessible

entries.text: I am not sure if this is still open to discussion, or if it is a done decision, but I am quite sure the Perl 5 Porters will want to hear your opinion on the subject. Should CGI.pm be removed from 'standard perl'?
entries.title: Ejecting CGI.pm From the Perl Core

entries.author: joel_berger
entries.text: Joel Berger responds to the idea of removing some code from the core of Perl.
entries.title: On the removal of some core modules

entries.text: .. and Chris Fedde too
entries.title: Response to Ejecting CGI.pm From the Perl Core

entries.author: mark_fowler
entries.text: Mark Fowler shows the difference between perl 5.16.3 and the recently released perl 5.18.0 regarding hash keys.
entries.title: 5.18 Hash Key Ordering Changes In A Nutshell

entries.author: david_golden
entries.text: There are cases when you would like to make sure your code runs on more than one version of Perl. Either because you don't have control over which version of perl will be used, or because your company wants to make sure when upgrade comes, it will be smooth. David Golden explains how he uses perlbrew to have several versions of perl on his system.
entries.title: How I manage new perls with perlbrew

entries.text: So if I understand this, the Num type will be stricter. I wonder how many applications will start throwing exceptions after upgrading to this version of Moose, and if those exceptions are correct there?
entries.title: Moose's Num won't be using Scalar::Util::looks_like_number as of Moose 2.1000

entries.author: tokuhiro_matsuno
entries.text: Tokuhiro Matsuno show a small script to use Compiler::Lexer, a Lexical Analyzer for Perl 5.
entries.title: CLI for Compiler::Lexer

entries.text: Christopher Frenz posted his slides about Information Retrieval and Extraction.
entries.title: NY Perl Mongers Talk Slides

entries.author: brian_d_foy
entries.text: brian d foy was at the Polish Perl Workshop and gave a presentation on how to find out which CPAN packages (name and version number) were installed in a certain environment.
entries.title: Reverse installing CPAN, at the Polish Perl Workshop

entries.text: Jay runs the central web site of the Perl Mongers. He creates (and deletes) the groups and helps people get started. In his spare time he ..., but I think you should just watch the interview. (24:17 min)
entries.title: Jay Hannah, Chief Ticket Monkey of the Perl Mongers

entries.author: gianluca_casati
entries.text: PHP was recently added to the Google App Engine as one of the supported languages. Gianluca Casati thinks that it would be important to have Perl there, and that you can increase  the chances by star-in the request on the issue list of GAE.
entries.title: We want Perl on GAE!

entries.text: While it is not specific to Perl, this article by the Booking.com people is quite interesting. Especially to those who participate in the localization of web sites. Like the Perl Maven contributors.
entries.title: On the importance of localisation

entries.author: laurent_dami
entries.text: What do you get in $x and $y in this code? my @tab = ( 1, 3, 6..9 ); my $x = @tab; my $y = ( 1, 3, 6..9 );
entries.title: A Perl Quiz by Laurent Dami

entries.author: rob_lauer
entries.text: Rob Lauer started to build a cloud-based business using Perl. This is the last entry in his series about building the business.
entries.title: Last in the 5 Part Series...

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: There are many ways to measure the 'market share' or 'mind share' of a programming language and the dynamics between languages. I tried to see how many people search for the respective terms and what are the trends in relative volume of searches.
entries.title: Perl, Python, Ruby, PHP and HTML5 on Google trends

entries.text: If you don't know how to use databases with Perl, this is a simple introduction for you, already translated to several languages. If you do know how to use databases but don't know who is Little Bobby Tables, then you definitely need to take a look.
entries.title: Simple Database access using Perl DBI and SQL

entries.text: June 3-5, 2013, Austin, Texas, USA
entries.title: YAPC::NA 2013

entries.text: June 14-15, 2013, Nancy, France
entries.title: French Perl Workshop 2013

entries.text: August 12-14, 2013, Kiev, Ukraine
entries.title: YAPC::EU 2013

entries.text: September 19-21, 2013, Keio University Hiyoshi Campus, Tokyo, Japan
entries.title: YAPC::Asia Tokyo

chapters.header: I usually list the next 3-4 events here. The list of all the events can be found on the web site. If your Perl event is not listed there, please let me know.
chapters.title: Events

header: While I am getting prepared for YAPC::NA, I felt I have to launch this thing now, or I will just keep delaying it forever. So I came up with the unofficial launch of the Perl Maven Pro subscription service. Even though it is unofficial I am nervous and excited. Will you want it?
subject: YAPC::NA starts in a week from today!
